bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 9, 1947

div1.p: Kean remembers a conversation with Gorgas, who believed that Reed had found a way of producing mild, non-fatal yellow fever. As such, Gorgas planned to start inducing experimental cases. Kean comments on the planned commemoration of Reed by the Fourth International Congress of Tropical Medicine and Malaria. He hopes that they will include a Cuban speaker for the event.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, September 9, 1947
div1.opener:
1-
Sep 9, 1947
2804 N St. N. W. Washington 7 D. C. 9/9/'47
My dear Colonel Hench
div1.p:
Cornelia thinks you may be interested in
a letter which came from Cuba today and in my
reply to it- I have a very clear recollection of my
talk with Gen. Gorgas in the summer of 1901 and his
telling me that he believed that Reed had found a
way of producing a mild non-fatal form of yellow
fever and he was going to start (or had started) a series
of experimental cases, and when he got 100 cases with-
out a death he would have Aileen (his daughter) bitten
and made immune- I have the record of his series of
7 cases with names and dates somewhere with the
three deaths, all of the deaths, I think being from one
mosquito, who was evidently loaded for bears, as the old
saying is- Just where the record is I dont know as I
have not a set of files with a clever girl in charge
as you have. I have however always at hand that bound
volume on Yellow Fever (Senate Doc. no. 822) which I got to-
gether and got the Surgeon General to have printed as a public
document- In the back of it is Gorgas's Final Report to Gen-
Wood being his last report as Chief Sanitary Officer of Havana-
It is dated July 12 1902, more than 2 months after we left Cuba
It reviews the history of the Sanitary Dept from its inception in 1899
2-
but does not mention the Las Animas Series of
yellow fever experiments, which had such a sad termi
nation. But I find in the Report of Dr. Carlos Finlay which
precedes that of Gorgas on page 228 they are mentioned in
a little table at the top of the page- I suppose the other two
experimental cases in Oct. and Nov- are the the two cases
of Carroll with filtered blood- But Finlay as you will
see gives no details- The less said the better it may be agreed-
I had a letter recently from Dr Wilbur A. Sawyer about the
Fourth International Congress of Tropical Medicine and Mala-
ria which will be held here May 10-18, 1948- He says
--“-it is planned to commemorate the demonstration by Walter
Reed of the mosquito transmission of yellow fever and to celebrate
his admission to the Hall of Fame”- This will be at one Eve-
ning meeting on Wed. May 12, '48- If you have not heard
of it you will in due time, for you are on the program
to make the chief address- All he wanted of me was to be a
member of the committee which I of course will accept
with pleasure- I wrote to him, if he was in favor of inter-
national peace, to make a place in the program for
some Cuban orator to tell of the contribution of Dr. Carlos Finlay,
wont they blow up if Finlay is left out! Siler is elected
Chairman of the Committee and we will agree that they
have made a good start with his selection-
